title: Readings in Religion and Ethnography
description: This reading seminar examines the range of methodological orientations and representational techniques in ethnographic writing about religion. It takes a critical approach to this topic, recognizing that there is always a politics and an ethics to the ways that scholars approach their subjects. We engage a set of theoretical concepts that inform recent ethnographic work that takes up religion. We ask questions like: What strategies have ethnographers used to represent religion as concept, as practice, as subject? What makes “ethnography of religion” different from an ethnography that does not take religion as a primary concern? Is there such a thing as a secular ethnography? As we go, we pay close attention to the research methods that the authors employ and the genre choices that they make in representing their subjects. The first part of the course centers queer, feminist, postcolonial, and critical race critiques of ethnography as epistemological and representational practice. We carry these critiques with us into the next parts of the term, when we turn to published works that attempt to reimagine what an ethnographic project can be and should do—in realms of authorial voice, theoretical breadth, intellectual focus, political critique, and beyond.
